sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: I’m Jihad Al Sayed, and in this video, we’re introducing determinants — a scalar value that tells you something deep about a matrix: whether it's invertible, how it scales space, and how vectors relate inside it.

sections.title: What Is a Determinant?
sections.content: A determinant is a number associated with a square matrix. It gives insight into the matrix’s properties — like invertibility, area/volume scaling, and linear dependence.

sections.title: Determinant of a 3x3 Matrix (Expansion by Minors)
sections.math: \det(A) = a(ei − fh) − b(di − fg) + c(dh − eg)

sections.title: Geometric Interpretation
sections.content: In 2D, the determinant represents the area of the parallelogram formed by two column vectors. In 3D, it gives the volume of a parallelepiped.

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: We introduced determinants, learned how to compute them for 2x2 and 3x3 matrices, and understood their geometric meaning. Determinants are compact, powerful, and everywhere in linear algebra.
